facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 275 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the order dated August 17, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in an application for leave to appeal to this companyrt in Appeal No. 254 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from order dated August 17, 1965 of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated August 17, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in an application for leave to appeal to this companyrt in Appeal No. 254 of 1963. WITH Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 2195 of 1965  Petition for Condonation of delay .

facts.text: Respondents obtained import licence on March 31, 1959 for machinery from West Germany with CIF value Rs. 45,000.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1959 the respondents obtained a licence to import certain machinery from West Germany. The import licence companytained particulars of the machinery to be imported and inter alia stated that its value would be I.F. value of Rs. 45,000.

facts.text: Licence condition: valid if actual value exceeds CIF by not more than five per cent.

anchor.surface_text: One of the companyditions upon which the licence was issued was that the above application is accepted and import licence is granted having quantity and value as the limiting factor and is number valid for clearance if the actual value of any item exceeds the C.I.F. value indicated in the licence by more than five per cent.

facts.text: Machinery arrived at Calcutta port in July 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The machinery arrived at the port of Calcutta sometime in July 1960 and was allowed to be cleared on the bill of entry submitted on behalf of the respondents.

facts.text: Bill of entry showed CIF value Rs. 44,843.61.

anchor.surface_text: The bill of entry showed the C.I.F. value of the machinery at Rs. 44,843.61 nP. The customs authorities thereafter assessed the duty payable on the said machinery and the duty so assessed was paid by the respondents.

facts.text: Customs duty assessed and paid by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The customs authorities thereafter assessed the duty payable on the said machinery and the duty so assessed was paid by the respondents.

facts.text: Search conducted on May 6, 1961 of respondents' premises and Stahlumon Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: On May 6, 1961, in companysequence of certain information received by the authorities a search was made of the business premises of the respondents and also of Stahlumon Co.,. Ltd., the agents of the exporters.

facts.text: Documents and papers seized by customs authorities during search.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the search certain documents and papers were seized by the customs authorities.

facts.text: Show cause notice served June 19/20, 1961 alleging illegal import of goods worth Rs. 6,730.74 excess.

anchor.surface_text: On June 19/20, 1961 a numberice was served upon the respondents calling upon them to show cause why action should number be taken against them under s. 167 8  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878. The numberice alleged that the respondents were guilty of illegal import of goods worth Rs. 6,730.74 nP, that being the excess value of the goods permitted to be imported under the said licence.

facts.text: Respondents gave explanation to show cause notice.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in due companyrse gave their explanation.

facts.text: Amended show cause notice dated September 21, 1961 under Sea Customs Act s.167(8) read with Imports and Exports Control Act s.3(2).

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter an amended show cause numberice dated September 21, 1961 was served upon the respondents charging them under s. 167 8  of the Sea Customs Act read with s. 3 2  of the Imports and Exports Control Act. 1947 for illegally importing the said companysignment.

facts.text: Personal hearing given to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were given a personal hearing and thereafter the first petitioner passed an order dated March 17, 1962 directing companyfiscation of the said machinery and imposing a tine of Rs. 20,000 in lieu of companyfiscation and further imposing a personal penalty of Rs. 25,000/-

facts.text: Order dated March 17, 1962 by first petitioner: confiscation of machinery, fine Rs.20,000 in lieu, personal penalty Rs.25,000.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter the first petitioner passed an order dated March 17, 1962 directing companyfiscation of the said machinery and imposing a tine of Rs. 20,000 in lieu of companyfiscation and further imposing a personal penalty of Rs. 25,000/-

facts.text: Respondents filed Art. 226 petition in High Court for mandamus and certiorari against March 17, 1962 order.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by this order the respondents filed a petition in the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for mandamus. directing the petitioners to rescind the order dated March 17, 1962 and for certiorari quashing the said order.

facts.text: Single Judge dismissed Art.226 petition on September 2, 1963 holding import illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge who heard the petition passed an order dated September. 2, 1963 dismissing the petition holding that the said. import was illegal.

facts.text: Appellate Bench of High Court allowed respondents' appeal on December 18, 1964, issued mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondents filed an appeal against the said order and the Appellate Bench of the High Court by its orders dated December 18, 1964 allowed the respondents appeal directing the petitioners to forbear from giving effect to the said order of the first petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioners applied for certificate under Art.133, dismissed on August 17, 1965 as barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The peti- tioners filed an application for a certificate under Art. 133 but the Appellate Bench of the High Court by its order dated August 17, 1964 dismissed the said application on the ground that it was barred by limitation, though holding that the valuation tests laid down in sub-cl.  a  and  b  of Art. 133 1  were satisfied,

facts.text: Certified copy of judgment furnished to petitioners on January 18, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The certified companyy of the judgment was furnished to the petitioners on January 18, 1965.

facts.text: Application for leave filed by petitioners on May 10, 1965 without certified copy of order.

anchor.surface_text: As the certified companyy of the said order was number finalised and was number ready the petitioners filed the said application for leave on May 10, 1965 annexing thereto the certified ,copy of the judgment only.

facts.text: Certified copy of order furnished on July 17, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On July 17, 1965, a certified companyy of the said order was furnished to the petitioners but they did number annex it to their application for leave as it was already filed.

facts.text: High Court dismissed application for leave on August 17, 1965 as time barred.

anchor.surface_text: As stated earlier, the High, Court dismissed the application by its order dated-August 17, 1965, on the ground that it was barred by limitation.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court dismissal, remands for decision on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the appeal and set aside the High Courts order of dismissal and remand the case directing the High Court to decide that application in the hot of this judgment and companysider whether the petitioners were entitled to leave under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 2195 of 1965 for condonation of delay.

issues.text: whether the application for leave to appeal was barred by limitation and the petitioners were not entitled under s. 12(2) of the Limitation Act to exclude the time taken in obtaining the certified copy of the said order

anchor.surface_text: The question for determination is whether the application for leave to appeal was barred by limitation and the petitioners were number entitled under s. 12 2  of the Limitation Act to exclude the time taken i

arguments.claim: Application for leave to appeal was barred by limitation as lodged on May 10, 1965, beyond 60 days from January 18, 1965 when certified copy of judgment was furnished

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondents, since under Art. 132 of the Limitation Act the application for leave had to be made within 60 days, the petitioners application lodged on May 10, 1965 was clearly beyond 60 days even after the certified copy of the judgment was furnished to them on January 18, 1965.

arguments.claim: On plain reading of s.12(2) and (3), time for certified copies of both judgment and order/decree must be excluded

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 2  provides that in companyputing the period of limitation for an appeal or application for leave to-appeal, the time requisite. for obtaining a companyy of the decree, sentence or order appealed from or sought to be revised shall be excluded.

arguments.claim: Object of s.12 exclusion is to allow appellant to consider terms of decree, judgment, order before launching appeal

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, under sub-section 3 where an application is made for leave to appeal, from a decree or order, the time requisite for obtaining a companyy of the judgment on which the decree or an order is founded shall also be excluded. On a plain reading of these sub-sections, it is clear that the time for obtaining the certified companyy of both the judgment and the decree or order as the case may be must be excluded while companyputing the period of limitation.

arguments.claim: s.12(2) enacts positive direction for exclusion irrespective of court rules or whether copy annexed

anchor.surface_text: In Surty v. Chettyar 1  the Privy Council after companyidering various decisions ,of different High Courts held that  1  the preponderance of practice in India was that time for obtaining a companyy of the judgment or decree or order should be excluded even thought under the rules of the Court it was number necessary to obtain a companyy of the judgment or decree to be filed with the memorandum of appeal,

arguments.claim: Gangaram Beharilal and Abdul Aziz wrongly hold s.12(2)(3) apply only if copy annexed

anchor.surface_text: But in Gangaram Beharilal 1  a view has been taken that sub-ss. 2 and 3 of s. 12 would only be attracted when a companyy of the judgment or decree or order appealed from accompanies the application for review. This view is number in companysonance with and in fact is companytrary to the interpretation of s. 12 by the Privy Council in Surtys Case 1  and is therefore unwarranted.

arguments.claim: Respondents' view leads to absurd result where waiting for order copy would make application in time but filing early without it time-barred

anchor.surface_text: The view companytended for on behalf of the respondents is thus number only companytrary to the decision of the Privy Council but if accepted would lead to a somewhat surprising result, viz., that if the petitioners had waited till the companyy of the order was furnished to them, their application would have been in time or if they had withdrawn their application and filed a fresh one or amended their application and annexed the companyy of the order such a fresh application,

arguments.claim: s.12(2)(3) positive direction prevails over court rules under CPC s.122

arguments.claim: s.12(2) and (3) provide unqualified positive exclusion of time for copies even if rules permit filing without them

anchor.surface_text: The other view is that sub-ss. 2 and 3 of s. 12 enact the rule of exclusion as a positive direction. The object of the sub-section being to afford a party opportunity to companyider his position even where a certified companyy of the judgment gives all the necessary information enabling the party to decide to proceed further or number, he would nevertheless be entitled to exclude the time for obtaining the certified companyy of the decree or order.

holdings.text: The High Court was not right in dismissing the petitioners' application for leave to appeal on the ground that it was barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in this view, therefore, was number right in dismissing the petitioners application for leave to appeal on the ground that it was barred by limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12(2) and (3) of Limitation Act mandate exclusion of time requisite for obtaining certified copies of both judgment and order irrespective of court rules requiring annexation or actual annexation thereof; follows Privy Council in Surty v. Chettyar; rejects contrary High Court views; avoids absurd consequences.

holdings.text: On a plain reading of sub-sections (2) and (3) of s.12 of the Limitation Act, the time for obtaining the certified copy of both the judgment and the decree or order must be excluded while computing the period of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading of these sub-sections, it is clear that the time for obtaining the certified companyy of both the judgment and the decree or order as the case may be must be excluded while companyputing the period of limitation. The object of the exclusion is to enable the person

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation; purposive to enable consideration of terms of judgment, decree, order before deciding to appeal.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.12(2) and (3) of Limitation Act are a positive direction excluding time taken in obtaining copy of judgment and decree or order irrespective of Code of Civil Procedure or rules made by court under s.122 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: direction excluding the time taken in obtaining a companyy of the judgment and decree or order as the case may be and those provisions are irrespective of the Code of Civil Procedure or the rules made by a companyrt under s. 122 of the Code. Such rules if they permit a memorandum

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grammatical construction and Privy Council in Surty v. Chettyar emphasize unconditional positive direction without reference to procedural rules; court rules confer privilege but do not override statutory exclusion.

holdings.text: Views in Gangaram Beharilal and Abdul Aziz v. Jai Ram that s.12(2),(3) apply only if copy accompanies application are contrary to Privy Council in Surty's case and unwarranted.

anchor.surface_text: But in Gangaram Beharilal 1  a view has been taken that sub-ss. 2 and 3 of s. 12 would only be attracted when a companyy of the judgment or decree or order appealed from accompanies the application for review. This view is number in companysonance with

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly conflicts with binding Privy Council interpretation of s.12 as positive direction independent of annexation.

holdings.text: Rule 4 Chapter XXXIIIA and Form No.3 of Calcutta High Court Rules do not require certified copy of judgment or order to be annexed to leave application nor lay down mandatory direction against annexing such copies.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4, in Chapter XXXIIIA of the Rules of the High Court requires that an application for leave to appeal shall be made by a numberice of motion before the appellate companyrt and shall be presented in the prescribed form, viz., Form No. 3. That form does number require

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct reading of rule and form enables filing without copies but does not prohibit annexation or affect statutory exclusion under Limitation Act.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court order dismissing leave application set aside; case remanded to High Court to decide application for certificate under Art.133 in light of this judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we allow the appeal and set aside the High Courts order of dismissal and remand the case directing the High Court to decide that application in the hot of this judgment and companysider whether the petitioners were entitled to leave under Art. 133

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequential to holding that application not time-barred; High Court held valuation tests satisfied and entitled otherwise.

holdings.text: No order need be passed on the petition for condonation of delay.

anchor.surface_text: entitled to leave under Art. 133 of the Constitution. As we are allowing the appeal. numberorder need be passed on the petition for companydonation of delay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Moot as appeal under Art.136 succeeds on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In Surty v. Chettyar 1  the Privy Council after companysidering various decisions ,of different High Courts held that  1  the preponderance of practice in India was that time for obtaining a companyy of the judgment or decree or order should be excluded even thought under the rules of the Court it was number necessary to obtain a companyy of the judgment or decree to be filed with the memorandum of appeal, and  2  that on a grammatical companystruction of s. 12 2 , the subsection plainly lays down a positive direction for exclusion of time without any reference to the Code of Civil Procedure or any other Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: time for obtaining a copy of the judgment or decree or order should be excluded even though under the rules of the Court it was not necessary to obtain a copy of the judgment or decree to be filed with the memorandum of appeal, and that on a grammatical construction of s. 12(2), the subsection plainly lays down a positive direction for exclusion of time without any reference to the Code of Civil Procedure or any other Act
precedents.cited_holding: s. 12 contained a positive direction for exclusion of time and that such direction applied irrespective of whether the rules permitted the filing of an appeal or an application without annexing the copy of the order or judgment

precedents.citation: Imperial Bucket Co. v. Smt. Bhagwati Basak 1

anchor.surface_text: In Imperial Bucket Co. v. Smt. Bhagwati Basak 1  there are however observations to the effect that an appellant will have the benefit of s. 12 in a case where he has annexed to the memorandum of appeal a certified companyy of the judgment appealed from even though by the statute under which the appeal is filed, numbercertified companyy of the order appealed from is required.

precedents.case_name: Imperial Bucket Co. v. Smt. Bhagwati Basak
precedents.cited_proposition: an appellant will have the benefit of s. 12 in a case where he has annexed to the memorandum of appeal a certified copy of the judgment appealed from even though by the statute under which the appeal is filed, no certified copy of the order appealed from is required

anchor.surface_text: But in Gangaram Beharilal 1  a view has been taken that sub-ss. 2 and 3 of s. 12 would only be attracted when a companyy of the judgment or decree or order appealed from accompanies the application for review.

precedents.cited_proposition: sub-ss. 2 and 3 of s. 12 would only be attracted when a copy of the judgment or decree or order appealed from accompanies the application for review

anchor.surface_text: The same must also be said of Abdul Aziz v. Jai Ram 1 . As observed by the Privy Council in Surtys Case   the view of the High Courts of Bombay, Calcutta and Allahabad as expressed in Haji Hassum v. Noor Mohammedan 5 , Kalipada v. Shakhar 6 , and Waji-Ali Shah v. Nawal Kishore 7  was that an appellant was entitled to exclusion of time in obtaining a companyy of a judgment and decree even though the rules permit him to file the appeal without annexing such a companyy.

Special Leave Petition 1110 of 1965 allowed to be withdrawn.
